news-item.title: Energy and Environment News Roundup - 3.14.14
news-item.text: Mar 14, 2014 (Earth and Industry:http://earthandindustry.com Delivered by Newstex) A daily roundup of the most important energy, environment, and climate news from around the world. OIL Crude oil shipments by rail increased 83 percent in 2013[1] (via New York Times) BP regains ability to bid on leases for US land and water[2] (via Washington Post) Report: Fracking could raise earthquake risks in California[3] (via Houston Chronicle) Average pump price passes $3.50 for first time in 6 months[4] (via Houston Chronicle) EMISSIONS Research: China's 'war on smog' won't cut CO2 by much[5] (via RTCC) Social cost of carbon greatly underestimated, says report[6] (via Climate Central) RENEWABLES Norway's oil fund may inject $40 billion in renewables[7] (via Renew Economy) Mexico boosts appeal as emerging solar market[8] (via Solar Industry Magazine) The burden of permitting, inspection, and interconnection on residential solar PV deployment[9] (via Energy Collective) California's grid sets two new solar energy records in two days[10] (via CleanTechnica) Xcel Energy awards $42 million for development of renewable energy projects[11] (via Renew Grid) US seeks comments on Virginia offshore wind[12] (via Recharge) It's official: Efficiency, clean energy can help fill California's nuclear generation gap[13] (via Renewable Energy World) Panasonic looks to California for solar-storage integration lessons[14] (via Greentech Media) KEYSTONE XL Beyond the hype, Keystone would yield few permanent jobs[15] (via Reuters) Keystone debate rages in Senate over health, climate effects[16] (via Houston Chronicle) Kerry says he hasn't prejudged Keystone XL[17] (via The Hill) Markey wants Keystone XL oil to stay in US[18] (via The Hill) Dems grapple with dilemma on Keystone XL[19] (via Washington Post) CLIMATE SEC's role in climate change[20] (via The Hill) Technology needed to combat climate change, says Murkowski[21] (via Bloomberg) Here's what the Chamber of Commerce thinks about global warming[22] (via National Journal) NATURAL GAS 16% of natural gas consumed in Europe flows through Ukraine[23] (via US EIA) Experts see cheaper way to turn natural gas into fuels[24] (via Reuters) Stakes high in mystery over Ohio fracking, quakes[25] (via Columbus Dispatch) COAL Emails link Duke Energy and North Carolina regulators[26] (via New York Times) North Carolina rejects Duke's coal ash plan, amid leniency accusations[27] (via News Observer) Utility quietly buying up homes near Wisconsin coal plant on groundwater pollution fears[28] (via Journal-Sentinel) 18 Ohio coal power plans operating with expired pollution permits[29] (via Columbus Dispatch) POLITICS Climate change showdown in Florida governor's race[30] (via InsideClimate News) Hanger withdraws from Pennsylvania governor's race[31] (via StateImpact Pennsylvania) OPINION Russia picks an odd time to put on climate halo[32] (via Bloomberg) Are US infrastructure needs truly urgent?[33] (via New York Times) How risky is investing in oil stocks?[34] (via CleanTechnica) Five things we learned from the Keystone XL Senate hearing[35] (via Climate Progress) Fourth time's the
